Fig. 1 The Mo16S36 cluster model used for the calculation. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Schematic diagram of thiophene (a) and the most stable adsorption structure (b) (sulfur: yellow, molybdenum: blue, carbon: gray, hydrogen: white) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Modes of thiophene adsorption observed in organometallic complexes. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Co-adsorption structure of thiophene and active hydrogen over corner site. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Calculated structures of the intermediates and transition states in the HYD pathway over corner site. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The energy profiles in the HYD pathway of thiophene over corner site. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Calculated structures of the intermediates and transition states in the DDS pathway over corner site. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The energy profiles in the DDS pathway of thiophene over corner site. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Possible thiophene HDS network over the corner site of MoS2 catalyst. Fig. 9 Table 1 Adsorption energies (kJ/mol) and bond length (Å) for adsorbed thiophene over corner site. Table 1 Eads Evdw d(S-Mo) d(S-C2) d(S-C5) d(C2-C3) d(C3-C4) d(C4-C5) Tgas/exp – – – 1.714 1.714 1.370 1.424 1.370 Tgas/cal – – – 1.720 1.720 1.375 1.421 1.376 Tads −75.13 −20.35 2.583 1.742 1.748 1.361 1.437 1.361 Table 2 An overview of the reactions involved in HDS of thiophene over corner site, CoMoS edge, the non-promoted Mo-edge and S-edge (kJ/mol). Table 2 Reaction Activation Energy Corner CoMoS [13] Mo edge [14] S edge [14] I 68.76 42.45 55.00 77.19 II 39.52 0.00 0.00 0.00 III 125.96 161.13 195.86 79.12 IV 30.75 92.63 13.51 157.27 V 72.76 60.79 106.13 20.26 VI 125.96 161.13 -- -- VII 4.30 0.00 -- -- VIII 49.50 0.96 -- -- IX 117.75 -- -- -- X 13.51 -- -- -- XI 200.18 -- -- -- Insights into the reaction pathway of thiophene hydrodesulfurization over corner site of MoS2 catalyst: A density functional theory study Shuo Li Yibin Liu Xiang Feng Xiaobo Chen Chaohe Yang ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, School of Chemical Engineering, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing School of Chemical Engineering China University of Petroleum Qingdao 266580 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Corner site, as the essential component of MoS2 catalyst, harbors tremendous significance in hydrotreating reactions. Mechanistic investigation on the catalytic performance of corner site is of burgeoning research interest. In this work, novel corner site model of MoS2 catalyst is constructed and the corresponding direct desulfurization pathway (DDS) and hydrogenation desulfurization pathway (HYD) are systematically investigated by DFT calculations using dispersion correction method. Based on energetic analysis, the cleavage of first C–S bond has the highest energy barrier in both DDS and HYD pathways. The energy barriers of the first C–S bond scission follow the order: 2-hydrothiophene <2,5-dihydrothiophene < tetrahydrothiophene, indicating that DDS is more favorable than HYD on corner site. Moreover, the activation energies of HYD and DDS pathways on 4 different active sites (Mo edge, S edge, CoMoS edge and corner) are further compared. Gratifyingly, both of HYD and DDS pathways are quite favorable over corner site. This work sheds new light on the design of efficient MoS2 catalysts for hydrodesulfurization reactions by increasing corner sites. Keywords Hydrodesulfurization Corner site MoS2 Reaction pathway DFT 1 Introduction Due to increasingly stringent environmental regulations of the sulfur content in transport fuels worldwide, hydrodesulfurization (HDS) has become one of the most indispensable processes in the petroleum refining industry [1,2]. In various HDS processes, the MoS2 based catalysts are the most widely used catalysts, which play a key role in increasing the process efficiency. To date, many efforts have been made to study the physico-chemical structure of the catalysts, the metal-support interactions, the effect of promoters, and the kinetics of the reactions [3–5]. Among others, the identification of active sites and the research on reaction pathways are quite essential and complex, which are of prime scientific and industrial importance. Due to the use of cutting-edge characterization techniques, such as scanning tunneling microscopy [6], the chemical natures of the MoS2 active sites are now well understood [7]. It has been confirmed that the basic MoS2 nanocluster is a finite single layer hexagonal 2H-MoS2 nanocluster. It is generally agreed that the coordinatively unsaturated active site (CUS) on the edges of the MoS2 cluster is actually active in HDS, while the basal plane is catalytically inactive [8]. Theoretically, at least three typical coordinatively unsaturated active sites exist on finite MoS2 nanoclusters: on the Mo edge, S edge and corner site. Particularly, the corner site exposes a highly accessible Mo site which allows the adsorption of sterically hindered molecules. Tuxen et al. [9] showed that the unsubstituted dibenzothiophene can only adsorb through its S atom over corner site. Meanwhile, sulfur vacancies are more stable over the corner site than those at the edges [10,11]. Besides, the highly dispersed supported MoS2 catalysts have predominant sizes in the range of 10–30 Å. At this level of dispersion, the proportion of corner site must be considerable [12]. Therefore, the corner site may play key roles in the HDS process. Thiophene is usually chosen as the probe to investigate hydrodesulfurization mechanism due to the small and benzene-like structure. Moses et al. [13,14] performed a detailed DFT investigation on thiophene HDS reaction on both Mo edge and S edge of MoS2 based catalysts. They pointed out hydrogenation reaction is most facile on the Mo edge and SC scission can only occur on the S edge. Recently, Ding et al. [15] reported that the corner sites of CoMoS nanocluster have high hydrogenolysis activity of the C–S bonds by investigation of the only full hydrogenation (FH) pathway. More recently, Jin et al. [16] have studied the thiophene HDS over the Mo-edge, the S-edge, and the Mo-S connection edge of MoS2 catalyst with 50% sulfur coverage using first-principles based microkinetic modeling. The Mo-S connection edge was acted as a bridge combined with Mo edge and S edge, which mainly associates with the migration of cis-2-butadienethiolate from the Mo edge to the S edge. Besides, the HDS reaction mechanism of thiophene is also well studied on the γ-Mo2N [2], S-modified MoP(010) [17], Re and ReSx catalysts [18]. However, few studies have been focused on the adsorption and reaction pathways (HYD and DDS) of thiophene HDS over the corner site of MoS2 catalyst. Therefore, an investigation on the pathways of thiophene HDS over corner site of MoS2 catalyst is urgently desired to gain profound insight into HDS mechanism of thiophene. It is widely accepted that direct observation of the active site or elucidation of transition state on the catalytic surface by experimental methods remains challenging. Therefore, density functional theory (DFT) is mainly used to investigate detailed mechanism of HDS over different active site [8]. In this work, the novel corner site of MoS2 catalyst was first constructed, and the HDS mechanism of thiophene over corner site was investigated by the DFT calculations using dispersion correction (DFT + D) method. Notably, the dispersion correction plays an indispensable role in calculating adsorption energies. It is found that the η1(S) adsorption configuration, with the S atom binding to the unsaturated Mo of corner site is more stable than others, due to the sterical hindrance. Possible reaction pathways were then investigated to identify the most favorable pathway of thiophene HDS over the corner site (sulfur coverage: Mo edge, 50%; S edge, 100%) by comparing the activation energy barriers on the potential surface at 0 K. Results show that the DDS pathway is more favorable than HYD pathway over the corner site. Moreover, the catalytic activation energies of HYD and DDS pathways over 4 different active sites (i.e., corner, S edge, CoMoS edge and Mo edge) of MoS2 catalyst are further compared, indicating that increasing corner sites in MoS2 is effective and beneficial to HDS reactions. This work is of referential importance to the design of effective MoS2 catalysts for hydrodesulfurization. 2 Computational methods The density functional calculations shown in this work were performed with the Dmol3 program package using the Materials Studio 8.0 of Accelrys Inc. [19]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) combined with Perdew-Wang 91 (PW91) functional [20] was used for treatment of the electronic structure in the calculations. For the numerical integration, we used the fine quality mesh size. The tolerances of energy, gradient and displacement convergence were 1 × 10−5 Ha, 0.002 Ha/Å and 0.005 Å. Spin states were explicitly set. The density functional theory plus dispersion calculations (DFT + D) [21] were carried out to estimate the effect of dispersion interactions to sorption and reaction based on the finding of Moses and Manos et al. [22,23] that vdW forces cannot be neglected in calculations of adsorption energies of aromatic and conjugated compounds on inert surfaces, such as the basal plane of MoS2. The complete linear synchronous transit (LST) and quadratic synchronous transit (QST) methods were used to find the transition state. Afterwards, the transition state was refined by optimizing the transition state following the eigenvector of the Hessian matrix corresponding to the imaginary frequency mode. Thus, it has been verified that the transition states have only one imaginary frequency. In this paper, the unique imaginary frequencies of all transition states involved in both DDS and HYD pathways of the thiophene HDS mechanism were calculated and provided in supplementary information (Table S1). All adsorption energies were calculated using the Eq. (1): (1) ΔEads= Eadsorbent-adsorbate - Eadsorbent - Eadsorbate Where Eadsorbent-adsorbate is the energy of the system with the molecule bound to the surface, Eadsorbent is the energy of the cluster, and Eadsorbate is the energy of the molecule in vacuum. 3 Model systems The dominant phase for bulk crystalline MoS2 is the 2H phase with AB stacking of the graphene-like hexagonal 2D sheets. Upon synthesis, the exposed surfaces are generally the (0001) basal plane of the S-Mo-S trilayer, the Mo-edge (10-10) and S-edge (-1010) [24]. Previous research demonstrated that the basal plane (0001) of MoS2 is inactive, and the hydrodesulfurization reactions take place on active edge sites of the MoS2 nanoparticles [25]. There are usually two models of catalysts, i.e., periodic model and cluster model. The periodic model only partially represents real catalyst structures, because it shows only edges, while real catalysts have boundaries in all directions. Therefore, cluster model with corners and edges on the catalyst surface represents the catalyst structures more realistically, and should describe the catalytic activity more precisely [26–28]. The structures of MoS2 cluster models with no support interactions are similar to the type II structures of highly active commercial catalysts [29]. Mo16Sx has been widely used as a cluster model in the field of HDS [30–32]. Recent STM and DFT studies showed that MoS2 clusters with a S coverage of 50% for Mo-edge and a S coverage of more than 50% were more stable [33–36]. The naked Mo-edge with the S coverage of 0% is energetically very unfavorable under HDS conditions [37]. Thus, Mo16S36 cluster model is selected, as shown in Fig. 1 . The S coverage of Mo edge is 50%, and 100% for S edge, respectively [14]. Coordinatively unsaturated corner sites naturally occur at the intersections of the Mo edge and S edge. After optimization, the average bond length of the Mo-Mo bond is 3.11 Å, and the average bond length of the S-Mo bond is 2.41 Å, which are similar to the experimental values of 3.16 and 2.41 Å, respectively [38,39]. Therefore, the model can represent the active phase of MoS2 catalyst. 4 Results and discussions 4.1 Adsorption of thiophene on corner site of MoS2 The structures and energies for the adsorption of thiophene over the corner site of the MoS2 catalysts are first investigated. The labeling convention for atoms in the thiophene ring is shown in Fig. 2 a, and the representative adsorption configuration is shown in Fig. 2b. The adsorption energies and some important geometric parameters of the relevant species are given in Table 1 . It is observed that the difference of bond lengths for free thiophene between calculated results (Tgas/cal) and experimental results (Tgas/exp) [40,41] is smaller than 0.006 Å, which shows that the calculation method used in this paper is reasonable and reliable. In addition, we found that the weak interaction between thiophene and cluster model has great influence on the adsorption energy. The total adsorption energy of thiophene (Eads) is −75.13 kJ/mol, while the weak interaction (Evdw) contributes -20.35 kJ/mol. This claims that the dispersion correction plays an essential role in the calculation process. Organometallic chemistry has provided a wealth of information concerning the bonding of thiophene to metal centers and its corresponding reactivity. Four different bonding modes have been observed for thiophene in organometallic complexes (Fig. 3 ) [42]. Among others, the η1(S) and η5 geometries have been suggested as the precursors to C–S bond cleavage for thiophene on HDS catalysts [43]. Due to the presence of S atoms around Mo atom at the corner site, the steric effect is formed. The Mo atom is thus difficult to have a strong interaction with the aromatic ring of the thiophene. So the adsorption energy of the η5 type at the corner site is very small (∼ -55.56 kJ/mol), as shown in Fig. S1. Compared with the η5 type, the η1(S) type has higher adsorption energy (−75.13 kJ/mol). This directly indicates that thiophene prefers to be adsorbed as the η1(S) type over corner site. Fig. 2b depicts the most stable adsorption structure of thiophene over the corner site. It can be seen that thiophene adsorbs preferentially in a tilted η1 (S) configuration, with the S atom in the binding position to a surface unsaturated Mo site (2.583 Å). This is in agreement with the IR observations [44], with a corresponding adsorption energy of −75.13 kJ/mol. Compared with bond lengths of thiophene in the gas-phase, the C–S and C3-C4 bonds in the adsorption state are slightly elongated by ∼0.028 Å. Nevertheless, the C2-C3 and C4C5 bonds are slightly stretched by ∼0.015 Å. Despite the structural variations, the adsorption process apparently causes only little influence on the ring aromaticity because changes of bond lengths are not substantial. This suggests that the interaction between thiophene and the corner site is mainly through the interaction between S and Mo atoms. Due to the presence of stable aromatic structure, the desulfurization reaction is difficult to take place when there is no active hydrogen. This is in good agreement with the results of Lauritsen [45] and Moser et al. [46], which suggest that desulfurization reactions could not take place without hydrogen or at low hydrogen pressure throughout the experiment. 4.2 Reaction mechanism of thiophene HDS The desulfurization pathways of thiophene over the corner site are then systematically investigated. It is widely accepted that desulfurization reactions require the activation of hydrogen on the catalyst surface and the subsequent reactions between adsorbed hydrogen species and sulfur-containing molecules. Experimental studies have suggested that the H2 dissociation is not the rate-determining step of thiophene HDS [47]. Meanwhile, DFT studies showed that the active H atoms can easily transfer over the surface of the catalyst [48,49]. Thus, H2 dissociation is not the case under HDS conditions. Herein, the thiophene HDS steps are investigated in the form of successive atomic hydrogen addition (i.e., monohydrogenation). The adsorbed H of both the surface S-H species and the Mo-H species can migrate to the adsorbed thiophene. 4.2.1 HYD pathway The active hydrogen over the corner site is co-adsorbed with thiophene, and the optimized structure model is shown in Fig. 4 . Using the energy of structure (Fig. 4a) as a benchmark, the relative energy (Erel) of the other structures was calculated. The results show that the relative energy of the structures with active hydrogen located on the S2, S3 and Mo is 59.74, 72.43 and 84.87 kJ/mol, respectively. This indicates that the structure with active hydrogen located on the S1 is the most stable configuration, in which the active hydrogen locates close to the thiophene ring. Thus, the structure (Fig. 4a) is used as the initial configuration for the study of the HDS reaction mechanism. The HYD has partial hydrogenation (PH) and full hydrogenation (FH) pathways. To simplify the subsequent discussion, the configurations of the intermediates and transition states involved in partial hydrogenation pathway and full hydrogenation pathway are listed in the Fig. 5 . Fig. 4a (same as Structure 1 in Fig. 5) shows that the distances between H and C2, C3, C4, C5 are 0.235, 0.268, 0.318 and 0.328 Å, respectively. It indicates that the H atom is much closer to the C2 atom. Therefore, the weakly-bound thiophene reacts further by addition of a hydrogen atom to C2, forming 2-hydro-thiophene-3-yl (Structure 2 in Fig. 5) with a calculated barrier of 68.76 kJ/mol. The C3 will then form a C–S bond with the corner sulfur (Structure 3 in Fig. 5), which is a non-activated process. The corresponding adsorption energy is -64.25 kJ/mol. It suggests that the surface nonmetal atoms can play a role over surface-molecule interaction, as shown by other researchers in similar systems [50]. 2,5-DHT (Structure 5 in Fig. 5) is formed by the second hydrogen addition with a calculated barrier of 39.5 kJ/mol. After that, the partial hydrogenation pathway proceeds by an initial C–S bond scission reaction with cis-2-butenethiolate as a product (Structure 7 in Fig. 5). The existence of the true transition state (Structure T3 in Fig. 5) has been confirmed by frequency calculations, resulting in one imaginary frequency at −266i cm−1. This is related to the cleavage of the first C–S bond. It is found that the C–S bond can be broken without involving one H atom. Finally, butadiene (Structure 8″ in Fig. 5) is formed through direct cleavage of the second C–S bond. At the transition state (Structure T4’’ in Fig. 5), the only imaginary frequency is found at -256i cm−1, related to the cleavage of the second C–S bond. The configurations from structure 6 to structure 10 in Fig. 5 show another partial hydrogenation pathway. Herein, cis-2-butenethiolate (Structure 7 in Fig. 5) is hydrogenated to the structure 8 (C4H7S). The calculated imaginary frequency of the transition state T4 is -659i cm−1, corresponding to the movement of H from SH group to C2 atom. Thereafter, the cis-2-butene (Structure 10 in Fig. 5) will be formed via hydrogenolysis reaction from the structure 9. At the transition state T5, only one imaginary frequency has been calculated at -429i cm−1. The full hydrogenation pathway is shown in Fig. 5 (Structure 6 to Structure 11′), in which thiophene is first hydrogenated to the THT, and then the cleavage of the C–S bond occurs via hydrogenolysis reaction. The structure 7’, 9’ and 11’ are 2,3,5-trihydrothiophene, tetrahydrothiophene and n-butyl thiolate. The imaginary frequencies of transition states T3’, T4’ and T5’, corresponding to the movement of the H atom from the catalyst to C atom are -488i, −922i and −1600i cm−1, respectively. The potential energy profile of different pathways mentioned above is shown as Fig. 6 . The first C–S bond cleavage has the highest energy barrier in the pH and FH pathways, with the values of 125.96 and 200.18 kJ/mol. This indicates that the desulfurization of 2,5-DHT is more facile than that of THT. Thus, the PH pathway is more favorable than the FH, which is in good agreement with the previous study of Shi [51]. 4.2.2 DDS pathway The calculated structures of the intermediates and transition states in the DDS pathway over corner site are listed in Fig. 7 , and the calculated potential energy profile is shown in Fig. 8 . As described in the previous study [14], the DDS pathway is characterized by the initial SC scission reaction occurring immediately after the formation of 2-MHT. Thus, the first step after adsorption of thiophene is hydrogenation to 2-MHT (Structure 2 in Fig. 7), which is followed by SC bond scission to cis-butadienethiolate (Structure 3 in Fig. 7) with an activation energy of 72.76 kJ/mol. Then the second H atom transfers to the C atom bonding to the S atom, the activation energy of which is 49.50 kJ/mol. The final S removal from cis-2-butadienethiolate is through the direct C–S bond cleavage with activation energy of 30.42 kJ/mol. The final product of the DDS pathway is butadiene (Structure 5 in Fig. 7). Herein, the first SC bond scission also has the highest energy barrier. A detailed description of the thiophene HDS over the corner site of MoS2 catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 9 . The results show that 2-MHT, 2,5-DHT and THT are all important intermediates in thiophene HDS process, which have different degrees of hydrogenation. Through the energy profiles in Fig. 6 and Fig. 8, the stability of these species follows the order: THT > 2,5-DHT > 2-MHT. This can provide a good explanation that 2-MHT can hardly observed in the experiment, while THT can be observed easily. Besides, different degrees of thiophene hydrogenation have different activation energy and reaction mechanism of the first C–S bond scission. Over the corner sites, the activation energy of the first C–S bond scission follows the order: THT (200.2 kJ/mol) > 2,5-DHT (126.0 kJ/mol) > 2-MHT (72.8 kJ/mol). Moreover, the cleavage of the first C–S bond of 2-MHT and 2,5-MHT can occur without the attack of the active H, while the cleavage of the first C–S bond of THT proceed through the hydrogenolysis reaction. As for the reaction pathway, the DDS pathway and the HYD pathway share some common features. Firstly, the first C–S bond cleavage has the highest energy barrier in both cases. Secondly, the second C–S bond scission barrier is much lower than the first C–S bond scission barrier. This indicates that thiol HDS is much easier to occur than the thiophene compounds HDS. Thirdly, butadiene is the main initial product both in HYD and DDS pathways. So the mixed butane and butene in the final product are produced by hydrogenation and isomerization, which is in agreement with the experimental results [52–54]. It is obvious that the DDS pathway is more favorable than the HYD pathway, because of the lower energy barrier (72.8 kJ/mol). Various experimental studies have presented apparent activation energies in range of 60.2–72.8 kJ/mol [55] and 69–98 kJ/mol [56]. The barriers found in the present study appear to compare well with the experimental values. Therefore, thiophene HDS more easily occurs though the DDS pathway over the corner site on MoS2 catalyst. 4.3 HDS activity of different active sites on MoS2-based catalyst The elementary reactions of thiophene HDS with activation energy are listed in Table 2 to simplify the subsequent discussion. For the HYD pathway, the partial hydrogenation pathway occurs in the following order: I-II-III-IV or I-II-VI-VIII, in which 2,5-DHT is the vital intermediate. The full hydrogenation pathway follows the order: I-II-IX-X-XI. The DDS pathway follows the order: I-V-VII. By comparing the activation energy in Table 2, it is found that different active sites for MoS2-based catalysts have different catalytic activities. It is interesting that sulfur removal from corners is much easier than from edges. This suggests that corners might play a key role in catalytic properties of non-promoted MoS2 particles [33]. Herein, the pathways of HYD and DDS are mainly discussed without considering the regeneration of active sites. For HYD pathway, the elementary step of highest energy barrier is the formation of cis-2-butenethiolate over the Mo edge, CoMoS edge and corner site with the activation energy of 195.86, 161.13 and 125.96 kJ/mol, respectively. While the elementary step of highest energy barrier over the S edge is the H transfer reaction to form cis-2-butenethiol with activation energy of 157.27 kJ/mol. Therefore, the corner site is more active for the HYD pathway. Moreover, the activation energy of the formation of cis-2-butenethiolate follows the order: Mo edge > CoMoS edge > corner site > S edge (79.12 kJ/mol). The different reaction barrier is ascribed to strength of interaction between the reactant and the active sites. There is no CUS over the Mo edge and CoMoS edge. However, corner site and S edge have CUS sites. Besides, the reactant can interact with two Mo atoms of the CUS over the S edge, while only one over the corner site. For DDS pathway, the elementary step of highest energy barrier is the first C–S bond scission of 2-MHT over the Mo edge, CoMoS edge and corner site with the activation energy of 106.13, 60.79 and 72.76 kJ/mol, respectively. Over the S edge it is the first hydrogenation to 2-MHT with an activation energy of 77.19 kJ/mol. Compared with the above data, the results show that the DDS pathway plays a major role over the above active sites. Although the activity of corner site for HYD and DDS pathway is less active than that of CoMoS edge, it is more active than that of Mo edge and S edge. Thus, the efficiency of HDS can be improved by increasing the corner/edge ratio. This work might shed new light on the design of highly effective MoS2 catalysts for HDS. 5 Conclusions Over corner site of MoS2 catalyst, the direct (DDS) and hydrogenation desulfurization (HYD) pathways were investigated by the DFT calculation with dispersion force correction (DFT + D) method. Adsorption calculations showed that thiophene absorbs preferentially in a titled η1(S) configuration with the S atom binding to the unsaturated Mo. Its corresponding adsorption energy is −75.13 kJ/mol, in which van der Waals forces contribute to −20.35 kJ/mol. Remarkably, the dispersion correction cannot be neglected in calculations of adsorption energies. Comparing the energy barriers, the cleavage of the C–S bond has highest energy barrier in different pathways, the activation barriers of which follow the order: 2-hydrothiophene (72.8 kJ/mol) < 2,5-dihydrothiophene (126.0 kJ/mol) < tetrahydrothiophene (200.2 kJ/mol). That indicates that the corner site exhibits high desulfurization activity via the DDS pathway of thiophene. Butadiene is the major initial product in both HYD and DDS pathways. Compared the results with previous DFT studies, the results demonstrate that the corner site plays an important role in the HDS of thiophene compounds. Declarations of interest None. coredata.dc:description: Corner site, as the essential component of MoS2 catalyst, harbors tremendous significance in hydrotreating reactions. Mechanistic investigation on the catalytic performance of corner site is of burgeoning research interest. In this work, novel corner site model of MoS2 catalyst is constructed and the corresponding direct desulfurization pathway (DDS) and hydrogenation desulfurization pathway (HYD) are systematically investigated by DFT calculations using dispersion correction method. Based on energetic analysis, the cleavage of first C–S bond has the highest energy barrier in both DDS and HYD pathways. The energy barriers of the first C–S bond scission follow the order: 2-hydrothiophene <2,5-dihydrothiophene < tetrahydrothiophene, indicating that DDS is more favorable than HYD on corner site. Moreover, the activation energies of HYD and DDS pathways on 4 different active sites (Mo edge, S edge, CoMoS edge and corner) are further compared. Gratifyingly, both of HYD and DDS pathways are quite favorable over corner site. This work sheds new light on the design of efficient MoS2 catalysts for hydrodesulfurization reactions by increasing corner sites.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into the reaction pathway of thiophene hydrodesulfurization over corner site of MoS2 catalyst: A density functional theory study
